Education is historically ignored in these countries. Add this to the new form of socialism called """"bolivarianism"""", with its particular mix of corruption and incompetence, and one easily sees that this had to happen as soon as the commodities boom slowed down. Nothing to see here, really. Chile is an exception. It has more liberal policies, and a good education system. Colombia is following on the right direction too.

Yep this is just something extra she could do specifically for other families with a disabled member. That's no bad thing. If I was entitled to DLA for having a disabled son but earnt literally millions and millions of pounds I would donate it to families with more need than I. I actually have a disabled brother and DLA is very strict and they're constantly reviewing it, reducing the amount and trying to take away the help he needs. Therefore I can think of a few families who aren't mega rich who are probably in the same boat as my brother and struggling.

My husband and I just spent a month in the USA, traveling the West coast. We would only order one meal to share as the portions were enormous, even then we had too much on our plates. All around us would be families with children, all consuming full plates of food.
